The Complexity of Weighted Boolean #CSP

Martin Dyer
School of Computing
University of Leeds
Leeds LS2 9JT, UK    Leslie Ann Goldberg
Department of Computer Science,
University of Liverpool,
Liverpool L69 3BX, UK    Mark Jerrum
School of Mathematical Sciences,
Queen Mary, University of London
Mile End Road, London E1 4NS, UK
(28 April 2008)
Abstract

This paper gives a dichotomy theorem for the complexity of computing the partition function of an instance of a weighted Boolean constraint satisfaction problem. The problem is parameterised by a finite set ℱℱ\mathcal{F} of non-negative functions that may be used to assign weights to the configurations (feasible solutions) of a problem instance. Classical constraint satisfaction problems correspond to the special case of 0,1-valued functions. We show that computing the partition function, i.e. the sum of the weights of all configurations, is FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}-complete unless either (1) every function in ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is of “product type”, or (2) every function in ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is “pure affine”. In the remaining cases, computing the partition function is in P.

1 Introduction

This paper gives a dichotomy theorem for the complexity of the partition function of weighted Boolean constraint satisfaction problems. Such problems are parameterised by a set ℱℱ\mathcal{F} of non-negative functions that may be used to assign weights to configurations (solutions) of the instance. These functions take the place of the allowed constraint relations in classical constraint satisfaction problems (CSPs). Indeed, the classical setting may be recovered by restricting ℱℱ\mathcal{F} to functions with range {0,1}01\{0,1\}. The key problem associated with an instance of a weighted CSP is to compute its partition function, i.e., the sum of weights of all its configurations. Computing the partition function of a weighted CSP may be viewed a generalisation of counting the number of satisfying solutions of a classical CSP. Many partition functions from statistical physics may be expressed as weighted CSPs. For example, the Potts model [23] is naturally expressible as a weighted CSP, whereas in the classical framework only the “hard core” versions may be directly expressed. (The hard-core version of the antiferromagnetic Potts model corresponds to graph colouring and the hard-core version of the ferromagnetic Potts model is trivial — acceptable configurations colour the entire graph with a single colour.) A corresponding weighted version of the decision CSP was investigated by Cohen, Cooper, Jeavons and Krokhin [3]. This results in optimisation problems.

We use #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) to denote the problem of computing the partition function of weighted CSP instances that can be expressed using only functions from ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. We show in Theorem 4 below that if every function f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in\mathcal{F} is “of product type” then computing the partition function Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I) of an instance I𝐼I can be done in polynomial time. Formal definitions are given later, but the condition of being “of product type” is easily checked — it essentially means that the partition function factors. We show further in Theorem 4 that if every function f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in\mathcal{F} is “pure affine” then the partition function of Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I) can be computed in polynomial time. Once again, there is an algorithm to check whether ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is pure affine. For each other set ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, we show in Theorem 4 that computing the partition function of a #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) instance is complete for the class FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}. The existence of algorithms for testing the properties of being purely affine or of product type means that the dichotomy is effectively decidable.

1.1 Constraint satisfaction

Constraint Satisfaction, which originated in Artificial Intelligence, provides a general framework for modelling decision problems, and has many practical applications. (See, for example [18].) Decisions are modelled by variables, which are subject to constraints, modelling logical and resource restrictions. The paradigm is sufficiently broad that many interesting problems can be modelled, from satisfiability problems to scheduling problems and graph-theory problems. Understanding the complexity of constraint satisfaction problems has become a major and active area within computational complexity [7, 14].

A Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) typically has a finite domain, which we will denote by [q]={0,1​…,q−1}delimited-[]𝑞01…𝑞1[q]=\left\{0,1\ldots,q-1\right\} for a positive integer q𝑞q.111 Usually [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q] is defined to be {1,2,…,q}12…𝑞\left\{1,2,\ldots,q\right\}, but it is more convenient here to start the enumeration of domain elements at 0 rather than 1. A constraint language ΓΓ\Gamma with domain [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q] is a set of relations on [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. For example, take q=2𝑞2q=2. The relation R={(0,0,1)R=\{(0,0,1), (0,1,0)010(0,1,0), (1,0,0)100(1,0,0), (1,1,1)}(1,1,1)\} is a 3-ary relation on the domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}, with four tuples.

Once we have fixed a constraint language ΓΓ\Gamma, an instance of the CSP is a set of variables V={v1,…,vn}𝑉subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛V=\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\} and a set of constraints. Each constraint has a scope, which is a tuple of variables (for example, (v4,v5,v1)subscript𝑣4subscript𝑣5subscript𝑣1(v_{4},v_{5},v_{1})) and a relation from ΓΓ\Gamma of the same arity, which constrains the variables in the scope. A configuration σ𝜎\sigma is a function from V𝑉V to [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. The configuration σ𝜎\sigma is satisfying if the scope of every constraint is mapped to a tuple that is in the corresponding relation. In our example above, a configuration σ𝜎\sigma satisfies the constraint with scope (v4,v5,v1)subscript𝑣4subscript𝑣5subscript𝑣1(v_{4},v_{5},v_{1}) and relation R𝑅R if and only if it maps an odd number of the variables in {v1,v4,v5}subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣4subscript𝑣5\{v_{1},v_{4},v_{5}\} to the value 111. Given an instance of a CSP with constraint language ΓΓ\Gamma, the decision problem CSP(Γ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) asks us to determine whether any configuration is satisfying. The counting problem #CSP(Γ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) asks us to determine the number of (distinct) satisfying configurations.

Varying the constraint language ΓΓ\Gamma defines the classes CSP and #CSP of decision and counting problems. These contain problems of different computational complexities. For example, if Γ={R1,R2,R3}Γsubscript𝑅1subscript𝑅2subscript𝑅3\Gamma=\{R_{1},R_{2},R_{3}\} where R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}, R2subscript𝑅2R_{2} and R3subscript𝑅3R_{3} are the three binary relations defined by R1={(0,1),(1,0),(1,1)}subscript𝑅1011011R_{1}=\{(0,1),(1,0),(1,1)\}, R2={(0,0),(0,1),(1,1)}subscript𝑅2000111R_{2}=\{(0,0),(0,1),(1,1)\} and R3={(0,0),(0,1),(1,0)}subscript𝑅3000110R_{3}=\{(0,0),(0,1),(1,0)\}, then CSP​(Γ)CSPΓ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is the classical 2-Satisfiability problem, which is in P. On the other hand, there is a similar constraint language Γ′superscriptΓ′\Gamma^{\prime} with four relations of arity 3 such that 3-Satisfiability (which is NP-complete) can be represented in CSP​(Γ′)CSPsuperscriptΓ′\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma^{\prime}). It may happen that the counting problem is harder than the decision problem. If ΓΓ\Gamma is the constraint language of 2-Satisfiability above, then #CSP​(Γ)#CSPΓ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) contains the problem of counting independent sets in graph, and is #P-complete [22], even if restricted to 3-regular graphs [12].

Any decision problem CSP​(Γ)CSPΓ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in NP, but not every problem in NP can be represented as a CSP. For example, the question “Is G𝐺G Hamiltonian?” cannot naturally be expressed as a CSP, because the property of being Hamiltonian cannot be captured by relations of bounded size. This limitation of the class CSP has an important advantage. If P≠NPPNP\mbox{\sf P}\neq\mbox{\sf NP}, then there are problems which are neither in P nor NP-complete [16]. But, for well-behaved smaller classes of decision problems, the situation can be simpler. We may have a dichotomy theorem, partitioning all problems in the class into those which are in P and those which are NP-complete. There are no “leftover” problems of intermediate complexity. It has been conjectured that there is a dichotomy theorem for CSP. The conjecture is that CSP​(Γ)CSPΓ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in P for some constraint languages ΓΓ\Gamma, and CSP​(Γ)CSPΓ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is NP-complete for all other constraint languages ΓΓ\Gamma. This conjecture appeared in a seminal paper of Feder and Vardi [10], but has not yet been proved.

A similar dichotomy, between FP and #P-complete, is conjectured for #CSP [2]. The complexity classes FP and #P are the analogues of P and NP for counting problems. FP is simply the class of functions computable in deterministic polynomial time. #P is the class of integer functions that can be expressed as the number of accepting computations of a polynomial-time non-deterministic Turing machine. Completeness in #P is defined with respect to polynomial-time Turing reducibility [17, Chap. 18]. Bulatov and Dalmau [2] have shown in one direction that, if #CSP​(Γ)#CSPΓ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is solvable in polynomial time, then the constraints in ΓΓ\Gamma must have certain algebraic properties (assuming P≠#PP#P\mbox{\sf P}\neq\mbox{\sf\#P}). In particular, they must have a so-called Mal’tsev polymorphism. The converse is known to be false, though it remains possible that the dichotomy (if it exists) does have an algebraic characterisation.

The conjectured dichotomies for CSP and #CSP are major open problems for computational complexity theory. There have been many important results for subclasses of CSP and #CSP. We mention the most relevant to our paper here. The first decision dichotomy was that of Schaefer [19], for the Boolean domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}. Schaefer’s result is as follows.

Theorem 1 (Schaefer [19]).

Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a constraint language with domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}. The problem CSP​(Γ)CSPΓ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in P if ΓΓ\Gamma satisfies one of the conditions below. Otherwise, CSP​(Γ)CSPΓ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is NP-complete.

  1. (1)

    ΓΓ\Gamma is 00-valid or 111-valid.

  2. (2)

    ΓΓ\Gamma is weakly positive or weakly negative.

  3. (3)

    ΓΓ\Gamma is affine.

  4. (4)

    ΓΓ\Gamma is bijunctive.

We will not give detailed definitions of the conditions in Theorem 1, but the interested reader is referred to the paper [19] or to Theorem 6.2 of the textbook [7]. An interesting feature is that the conditions in [7, Theorem 6.2] are all checkable. That is, there is an algorithm to determine whether CSP(Γ\mbox{\sf CSP}(\Gamma) is in P or NP-complete, given a constraint language ΓΓ\Gamma with domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}. Creignou and Hermann [6] adapted Schaefer’s decision dichotomy to obtain a counting dichotomy for the Boolean domain. Their result is as follows.

Theorem 2 (Creignou and Hermann [6]).

Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a constraint language with domain {0,1}01\{0,1\}. The problem #CSP​(Γ)#CSPΓ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is in FP if ΓΓ\Gamma is affine. Otherwise, #CSP​(Γ)#CSPΓ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is #P-complete.

A constraint language ΓΓ\Gamma with domain {0,1}01\{0,1\} is affine if every relation R∈Γ𝑅ΓR\in\Gamma is affine. A relation R𝑅R is affine if the set of tuples x∈R𝑥𝑅x\in R is the set of solutions to a system of linear equations over GF(222). These equations are of the form v1⊕⋯⊕vn=0direct-sumsubscript𝑣1⋯subscript𝑣𝑛0v_{1}\oplus\cdots\oplus v_{n}=0 and v1⊕⋯⊕vn=1direct-sumsubscript𝑣1⋯subscript𝑣𝑛1v_{1}\oplus\cdots\oplus v_{n}=1 where ⊕direct-sum\oplus is the exclusive or operator. It is well known (see, for example, Lemma 4.10 of [7]) that a relation R𝑅R is affine iff a,b,c∈R𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑅a,b,c\in R implies d=a⊕b⊕c∈R𝑑direct-sum𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑅d=a\oplus b\oplus c\in R. (We will use this characterisation below.) There is an algorithm for determining whether a Boolean constraint language ΓΓ\Gamma is affine, so there is an algorithm for determining whether #CSP​(Γ)#CSPΓ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) is in FP or #P-complete.

1.2 Weighted #CSP

The weighted framework of [4] extends naturally to Constraint Satisfaction Problems. Fix the domain [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. Instead of constraining a length-k𝑘k scope with an arity-k𝑘k relation on [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q], we give a weight to the configuration on this scope by applying a function f𝑓f from [q]ksuperscriptdelimited-[]𝑞𝑘[q]^{k} to the non-negative rationals. Let ℱq={f:[q]k→ℚ+∣k∈ℕ}subscriptℱ𝑞conditional-set𝑓→superscriptdelimited-[]𝑞𝑘conditionalsuperscriptℚ𝑘ℕ\mathcal{F}_{q}=\{f:[q]^{k}\rightarrow\mathbb{Q}^{+}\mid k\in\mathbb{N}\} be the set of all such functions (of all arities).222We assume 0∈ℕ0ℕ0\in\mathbb{N}, so we allow non-negative constants. Given a function f∈ℱq𝑓subscriptℱ𝑞f\in\mathcal{F}_{q} of arity k𝑘k, the underlying relation of f𝑓f is given by Rf={x∈[q]k∣f​(x)≠0}subscript𝑅𝑓conditional-set𝑥superscriptdelimited-[]𝑞𝑘𝑓𝑥0R_{f}=\{x\in[q]^{k}\mid f(x)\not=0\}. It is often helpful to think of Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} as a table, with k𝑘k columns corresponding to the positions of a k𝑘k-tuple. Each row corresponds to a tuple x=(x1,…,xk)∈Rf𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑅𝑓x=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{k})\in R_{f}. The entry in row x𝑥x and column j𝑗j is xjsubscript𝑥𝑗x_{j}, which is a value in [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q].

A weighted #CSP problem is parameterised by a finite subset ℱℱ\mathcal{F} of ℱqsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}_{q}, and will be denoted by #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}). An instance I𝐼I of #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) consists of a set V𝑉V of variables and a set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} of constraints. Each constraint C∈𝒞𝐶𝒞C\in\mathcal{C} consists of a function fC∈ℱsubscript𝑓𝐶ℱf_{C}\in\mathcal{F} (say of arity kCsubscript𝑘𝐶k_{C}) and a scope, which is a sequence sC=(vC,1,…,vC,kC)subscript𝑠𝐶subscript𝑣𝐶1…subscript𝑣𝐶subscript𝑘𝐶s_{C}=(v_{C,1},\ldots,v_{C,k_{C}}) of variables from V𝑉V. The variables vC,1,…,vC,kCsubscript𝑣𝐶1…subscript𝑣𝐶subscript𝑘𝐶v_{C,1},\ldots,v_{C,k_{C}} need not be distinct. As in the unweighted case, a configuration σ𝜎\sigma for the instance I𝐼I is a function from V𝑉V to [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. The weight of the configuration σ𝜎\sigma is given by

w​(σ)=∏C∈𝒞fC​(σ​(vC,1),…,σ​(vC,kC)).𝑤𝜎subscriptproduct𝐶𝒞subscript𝑓𝐶𝜎subscript𝑣𝐶1…𝜎subscript𝑣𝐶subscript𝑘𝐶w(\sigma)=\prod_{C\in\mathcal{C}}f_{C}(\sigma(v_{C,1}),\ldots,\sigma(v_{C,k_{C}})).

Finally, the partition function Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I) is given, for instance I𝐼I, by

Z​(I)=∑σ:V→[q]w​(σ).𝑍𝐼subscript:𝜎→𝑉delimited-[]𝑞𝑤𝜎Z(I)=\sum_{\sigma:V\rightarrow[q]}w(\sigma). (1)

In the computational problem #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}), the goal is to compute Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I), given an instance I𝐼I.

Note that an (unweighted) CSP counting problem #CSP​(Γ)#CSPΓ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma) can be represented naturally as a weighted CSP counting problem. For each relation R∈Γ𝑅ΓR\in\Gamma, let fRsuperscript𝑓𝑅f^{R} be the indicator function for membership in R𝑅R. That is, if x∈R𝑥𝑅x\in R we set fR​(x)=1superscript𝑓𝑅𝑥1f^{R}(x)=1. Otherwise we set fR​(x)=0superscript𝑓𝑅𝑥0f^{R}(x)=0. Let ℱ={fR∣R∈Γ}ℱconditional-setsuperscript𝑓𝑅𝑅Γ\mathcal{F}=\{f^{R}\mid R\in\Gamma\}. Then for any instance I𝐼I of #CSP​(Γ)#CSPΓ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\Gamma), the number of satisfying configurations for I𝐼I is given by the (weighted) partition function Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I) from (1).

This framework has been employed previously in connection with graph homomorphisms [1]. Suppose H=(Hi​j)𝐻subscript𝐻𝑖𝑗H=(H_{ij}) is any symmetric square matrix H𝐻H of rational numbers. We view H𝐻H as being an edge-weighting of an undirected graph ℋℋ\mathcal{H}, where a zero weight in H𝐻H means that the corresponding edge is absent from ℋℋ\mathcal{H}. Given a (simple) graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) we consider computing the partition function

ZH​(G)=∑σ:V→[q]w​(σ),wherew​(σ)=∏{u,v}∈EHσ​(u)​σ​(v).formulae-sequencesubscript𝑍𝐻𝐺subscript:𝜎→𝑉delimited-[]𝑞𝑤𝜎where𝑤𝜎subscriptproduct𝑢𝑣𝐸subscript𝐻𝜎𝑢𝜎𝑣Z_{H}(G)=\sum_{\sigma:V\rightarrow[q]}w(\sigma),\quad\textrm{where}\ \ w(\sigma)=\prod_{\{u,v\}\in E}H_{\sigma(u)\sigma(v)}.

Within our framework above, we view H𝐻H as the binary function h:[q]2→ℝ:ℎ→superscriptdelimited-[]𝑞2ℝh:[q]^{2}\to\mathbb{R}, and the problem is then computing the partition function of #​C​S​P​({h})#𝐶𝑆𝑃ℎ\#CSP(\left\{h\right\}).

Bulatov and Grohe [4] call H𝐻H connected if ℋℋ\mathcal{H} is connected and bipartite if ℋℋ\mathcal{H} is bipartite. They give the following dichotomy theorem for non-negative H𝐻H.333This is not quite the original statement of the theorem. We have chosen here to restrict all inputs to be rational, in order to avoid issues of how to represent, and compute with, arbitrary real numbers.

Theorem 3 (Bulatov and Grohe [4]).

Let H𝐻H be a symmetric matrix with non-negative rational entries.

  1. (1)

    If H𝐻H is connected and not bipartite, then computing ZHsubscript𝑍𝐻Z_{H} is in FP if the rank of H𝐻H is at most 111; otherwise computing ZHsubscript𝑍𝐻Z_{H} is #P-hard.

  2. (2)

    If H𝐻H is connected and bipartite, then computing ZHsubscript𝑍𝐻Z_{H} is in FP if the rank of H𝐻H is at most 222; otherwise computing ZHsubscript𝑍𝐻Z_{H} is #P-hard.

  3. (3)

    If H𝐻H is not connected, then computing ZHsubscript𝑍𝐻Z_{H} is in FP if each of its connected components satisfies the corresponding conditions stated in (1) or (2); otherwise computing ZHsubscript𝑍𝐻Z_{H} is #P-hard.∎

Many partition functions arising in statistical physics may be viewed as weighted #CSP problems. An example is the q𝑞q-state Potts model (which is, in fact, a weighted graph homomorphism problem). In general, weighted #CSP is very closely related to the problem of computing the partition function of a Gibbs measure in the framework of Dobrushin, Lanford and Ruelle (see [1]). See also the framework of Scott and Sorkin [20].

1.3 Some Notation

We will call the class of (rational) weighted #CSP problems weighted #CSP. The sub-class having domain size q=2𝑞2q=2 will be called weighted Boolean #CSP, and will be the main focus of this paper. We will give a dichotomy theorem for weighted Boolean #CSP.

Since weights can be arbitrary non-negative rational numbers, the solution to these problems is not an integer in general. Therefore #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) is not necessarily in the class #P. However, Goldberg and Jerrum [11] have observed that Z​(I)=Z~​(I)/K​(I)𝑍𝐼~𝑍𝐼𝐾𝐼Z(I)=\tilde{Z}(I)/K(I), where Z~~𝑍\tilde{Z} is a function in #P and K​(I)𝐾𝐼K(I) is a positive integer computable in FP. This follows because, for all f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in\mathcal{F}, we can ensure that f​(⋅)=f~​(⋅)/K​(I)𝑓⋅~𝑓⋅𝐾𝐼f(\cdot)=\tilde{f}(\cdot)/K(I), where f~​(⋅)∈ℕ~𝑓⋅ℕ\tilde{f}(\cdot)\in\mathbb{N}, by“clearing denominators”. The denominator K​(I)𝐾𝐼K(I) can obviously be computed in polynomial time, and it is straightforward to show that computing Z~​(I)~𝑍𝐼\tilde{Z}(I) is in #P, so the characterisation of [11] follows. The resulting complexity class, comprising functions which are a function in #P divided by a function in FP, is named #Pℚsubscript#Pℚ\mbox{\sf\#P}_{\mathbb{Q}} in [11], where it is used in the context of approximate counting. Clearly we have

weighted​#CSP⊆#Pℚ⊆FP#P.weighted#CSPsubscript#PℚsuperscriptFP#P\textsf{weighted}\,\mbox{\sf\#CSP}\ \subseteq\ \mbox{$\mbox{\sf\#P}_{\mathbb{Q}}$}\ \subseteq\ \mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}.

On the other hand, if Z​(I)∈weighted​#CSP𝑍𝐼weighted#CSPZ(I)\in\textsf{weighted}\,\mbox{\sf\#CSP} is #P-hard, then, using an oracle for computing Z(IZ(I), we can construct a #P oracle Z~​(I)~𝑍𝐼\tilde{Z}(I) as outlined above. (Note that Z​(I)∉#P𝑍𝐼#PZ(I)\notin\mbox{\sf\#P} in general.) Using this, we can compute any function in FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}} with a polynomial time-bounded oracle Turing machine. Thus any #P-hard function in weighted #CSP is complete for FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}. We will use this observation to state our main result in terms of completeness for the class FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}.

We make the following definition, which relates to the discussion above. We will say that ℱ⊆ℱqℱsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{q} simulates f∈ℱq𝑓subscriptℱ𝑞f\in\mathcal{F}_{q} if, for each instance I𝐼I of #CSP​(ℱ∪{f})#CSPℱ𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\left\{f\right\}), there is a polynomial time computable instance I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} of #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}), such that Z​(I)=φ​(I)​Z​(I′)𝑍𝐼𝜑𝐼𝑍superscript𝐼′Z(I)=\varphi(I)Z(I^{\prime}) for some φ​(I)∈ℚ𝜑𝐼ℚ\varphi(I)\in\mathbb{Q} which is FP-computable. This generalises the notion of parsimonious reduction [17] among problems in #P. We will use ≤TsubscriptT\leq_{\mathrm{T}} to denote the relation “is polynomial-time Turing-reducible to” between computational problems. Clearly, if ℱℱ\mathcal{F} simulates f𝑓f, we have #CSP​(ℱ∪{f})≤T#CSP​(ℱ)subscriptT#CSPℱ𝑓#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\left\{f\right\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}). Note also that, if f~=K​f~𝑓𝐾𝑓\tilde{f}=Kf, for some constant K>0𝐾0K>0, then {f}𝑓\left\{f\right\} simulates f~~𝑓\tilde{f}. Thus there is no need to distinguish between “proportional” functions.

We use the following terminology for certain functions. Let χ=subscript𝜒\chi_{=} be the binary equality function defined on [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q] as follows. For any element c∈[q]𝑐delimited-[]𝑞c\in[q], χ=​(c,c)=1subscript𝜒𝑐𝑐1\chi_{=}(c,c)=1 and for any pair (c,d)𝑐𝑑(c,d) of distinct elements of [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q], χ=​(c,d)=0subscript𝜒𝑐𝑑0\chi_{=}(c,d)=0. Let χ≠subscript𝜒\chi_{\not=} be the binary disequality function given by χ≠​(c,d)=1−χ=​(c,d)subscript𝜒𝑐𝑑1subscript𝜒𝑐𝑑\chi_{\not=}(c,d)=1-\chi_{=}(c,d) for all c,d∈[q]𝑐𝑑delimited-[]𝑞c,d\in[q].444A more general disequality function is defined in the Appendix. We say that a function f𝑓f is of product type if f𝑓f can be expressed as a product of unary functions and binary functions of the form χ=subscript𝜒\chi_{=} and χ≠subscript𝜒\chi_{\neq}.

We focus attention in this paper on the Boolean case, q=2𝑞2q=2. In this case, we say that a function f∈ℱ2𝑓subscriptℱ2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} has affine support if its underlying relation Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, defined earlier, is affine. We say that f𝑓f is pure affine if it has affine support and range {0,w}0𝑤\{0,w\} for some w>0𝑤0w>0. Thus a function is pure affine if and only if it is a positive real multiple of some (0,1-valued) function which is affine over GF(2).

1.4 Our Result

Our main result is the following.

Theorem 4.

Suppose ℱ⊆ℱ2={f:{0,1}k→ℚ+∣k∈ℕ}ℱsubscriptℱ2conditional-set𝑓→superscript01𝑘conditionalsuperscriptℚ𝑘ℕ\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{2}=\{f:\left\{0,1\right\}^{k}\to\mathbb{Q}^{+}\mid k\in\mathbb{N}\}. If every function in ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is of product type then #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) is in FP. If every function in ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is pure affine then #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) is in FP. Otherwise, #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) is FP#PsuperscriptFP#P\mbox{\sf FP}^{\mbox{\scriptsize\sf\#P}}-complete.

Proof.

Suppose first that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is of product type. In this case the partition function Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I) of an instance I𝐼I with variable set V𝑉V is easy to evaluate because it can be factored into easy-to-evaluate pieces: Partition the variables in V𝑉V into equivalence classes according to whether or not they are related by an equality or disequality function. (The equivalence relation on variables here is “depends linearly on”.) An equivalence class consists of two (possibly empty) sets of variables U1subscript𝑈1U_{1} and U2subscript𝑈2U_{2}. All of the variables in U1subscript𝑈1U_{1} must be assigned the same value by a configuration σ𝜎\sigma of nonzero weight, and all variables in U2subscript𝑈2U_{2} must be assigned the other value. Variables in U1∪U2subscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2U_{1}\cup U_{2} are not related by equality or disequality to variables in V∖(U1∪U2)𝑉subscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2V\setminus(U_{1}\cup U_{2}). The equivalence class contributes one weight, say α𝛼\alpha, to the partition function if variables in U1subscript𝑈1U_{1} are given value “00” by σ𝜎\sigma and it contributes another weight, say β𝛽\beta, to the partition function if variables in U1subscript𝑈1U_{1} are given value “111” by σ𝜎\sigma. Thus, Z​(I)=(α+β)​Z​(I′)𝑍𝐼𝛼𝛽𝑍superscript𝐼′Z(I)=(\alpha+\beta)Z(I^{\prime}), where I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} is the instance formed from I𝐼I by removing this equivalence class. Therefore, suppose we choose any equivalence class and remove its variables. Since ℱℱ\mathcal{F} contains only unary, equality or binary disequality constraints, we can also remove all functions involving variables in U1∪U2subscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2U_{1}\cup U_{2} to give ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}. Then I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} is of product type with fewer variables, so we may compute Z​(I′)𝑍superscript𝐼′Z(I^{\prime}) recursively.

Suppose second that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} if pure affine. Then Z​(I)=∏f∈ℱwfkf​Z​(I′)𝑍𝐼subscriptproduct𝑓ℱsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑓subscript𝑘𝑓𝑍superscript𝐼′Z(I)=\prod_{f\in\mathcal{F}}w_{f}^{k_{f}}Z(I^{\prime}), where {0,wf}0subscript𝑤𝑓\{0,w_{f}\} is the range of f𝑓f, kfsubscript𝑘𝑓k_{f} is the number of constraints involving f𝑓f in I𝐼I, and I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} is the instance obtained from I𝐼I by replacing every function f𝑓f by its underlying relation Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} (viewed as a function with range {0,1}01\{0,1\}). Z​(I′)𝑍superscript𝐼′Z(I^{\prime}) is easy to evaluate, because this is just counting solutions to a linear system over GF(222), as Creignou and Hermann have observed [6].

Finally, the #P-hardness in Theorem 4 follows from Lemma 5 below. ∎

Lemma 5.

If f∈ℱ2𝑓subscriptℱ2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not of product type and g∈ℱ2𝑔subscriptℱ2g\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not pure affine then #CSP​({f,g})#CSP𝑓𝑔\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,g\}) is #P-hard.

Note that the functions f𝑓f and g𝑔g in Lemma 5 may be one and the same function. So #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) is #P-hard when f𝑓f is not of product type nor pure affine. The rest of this article gives the proof of Lemma 5.

2 Useful tools for proving hardness of #CSP

2.1 Notation

For any sequence u1,…,uksubscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑘u_{1},\ldots,u_{k} of variables of I𝐼I and any sequence c1,…,cksubscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑘c_{1},\ldots,c_{k} of elements of the domain [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q], we will let Z​(I∣σ​(u1)=c1,…,σ​(uk)=ck)𝑍formulae-sequenceconditional𝐼𝜎subscript𝑢1subscript𝑐1…𝜎subscript𝑢𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘Z(I\mid\sigma(u_{1})=c_{1},\ldots,\sigma(u_{k})=c_{k}) denote the contribution to Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I) from assignments σ𝜎\sigma with σ​(u1)=c1,⋯,σ​(uk)=ckformulae-sequence𝜎subscript𝑢1subscript𝑐1⋯𝜎subscript𝑢𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘\sigma(u_{1})=c_{1},\cdots,\sigma(u_{k})=c_{k}.

2.2 Projection

The first tool that we study is projection, which is referred to as “integrating out” in the statistical physics literature.

Let f𝑓f be a function of arity k𝑘k, and let J={j1,…,jr}𝐽subscript𝑗1…subscript𝑗𝑟J=\{j_{1},\ldots,j_{r}\} be a size-r𝑟r subset of {1,…,k}1…𝑘\{1,\ldots,k\}, where j1<⋯<jrsubscript𝑗1⋯subscript𝑗𝑟j_{1}<\cdots<j_{r}.555It is not necessary to choose this particular ordering for J𝐽J, but it is convenient to do so. We say that a k𝑘k-tuple x′∈[q]ksuperscript𝑥′superscriptdelimited-[]𝑞𝑘x^{\prime}\in[q]^{k} extends an r𝑟r-tuple x∈[q]r𝑥superscriptdelimited-[]𝑞𝑟x\in[q]^{r} on J𝐽J (written x′⊒Jxsubscriptsquare-original-of-or-equals𝐽superscript𝑥′𝑥x^{\prime}\sqsupseteq_{J}x) if x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} agrees with x𝑥x on indices in J𝐽J; that is to say, xji′=xisubscriptsuperscript𝑥′subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖x^{\prime}_{j_{i}}=x_{i} for all 1≤i≤r1𝑖𝑟1\leq i\leq r. The projection g𝑔g of f𝑓f onto J𝐽J is defined as follows. For every x∈[q]r𝑥superscriptdelimited-[]𝑞𝑟x\in[q]^{r}, g​(x)=∑x′⊒Jxf​(x′)𝑔𝑥subscriptsubscriptsquare-original-of-or-equals𝐽superscript𝑥′𝑥𝑓superscript𝑥′g(x)=\sum_{x^{\prime}\sqsupseteq_{J}x}f(x^{\prime}).

The following lemma may be viewed as a weighted version of Proposition 2 of [2], where it is proved for the unweighted case. It is expressed somewhat differently in [2], in terms of counting the number of solutions to an existential formula.

Lemma 6.

Suppose ℱ⊆ℱqℱsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{q}. Let g𝑔g be a projection of a function f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in\mathcal{F} onto a subset of its indices. Then #CSP​(ℱ∪{g})≤T#CSP​(ℱ)subscriptT#CSPℱ𝑔#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\{g\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}).

Proof.

Let k𝑘k be the arity of f𝑓f and let g𝑔g be the projection of f𝑓f onto the subset J𝐽J of its indices. Let I𝐼I be an instance of #CSP​(ℱ∪{g})#CSPℱ𝑔\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\{g\}). We will construct an instance I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} of #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) such that Z​(I)=Z​(I′)𝑍𝐼𝑍superscript𝐼′Z(I)=Z(I^{\prime}). The instance I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} is identical to I𝐼I except that every constraint C𝐶C of I𝐼I involving g𝑔g is replaced with a new constraint C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} of I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} involving f𝑓f. The corresponding scope (vC′,1,…,vC′,k)subscript𝑣superscript𝐶′1…subscript𝑣superscript𝐶′𝑘(v_{C^{\prime},1},\ldots,v_{C^{\prime},k}) is constructed as follows. If jℓsubscript𝑗ℓj_{\ell} is the ℓℓ\ell’th element of J𝐽J, then vC′,jℓ′=vC,ℓsubscriptsuperscript𝑣′superscript𝐶′subscript𝑗ℓsubscript𝑣𝐶ℓv^{\prime}_{C^{\prime},j_{\ell}}=v_{C,\ell}. The other variables, vC′,jsubscript𝑣superscript𝐶′𝑗v_{C^{\prime},j} (j∉J𝑗𝐽j\notin J), are distinct new variables. We have shown that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} simulates g𝑔g with ϕ​(I)=1italic-ϕ𝐼1\phi(I)=1. ∎

2.3 Pinning

For c∈[q]𝑐delimited-[]𝑞c\in[q], δcsubscript𝛿𝑐\delta_{c} denotes the unary function with δc​(c)=1subscript𝛿𝑐𝑐1\delta_{c}(c)=1 and δc​(d)=0subscript𝛿𝑐𝑑0\delta_{c}(d)=0 for d≠c𝑑𝑐d\neq c. The following lemma, which allows “pinning” CSP variables to specific values in hardness proofs, generalises Theorem 8 of [2], which does the unweighted case. Again [2] employs different terminology, and its theorem is a statement about the full idempotent reduct of a finite algebra. The idea of pinning was used previously by Bulatov and Grohe of [4] in the context of counting weighted graph homomorphisms (see Lemma 32 of [4]). A similar idea was used by Dyer and Greenhill in the context of counting unweighted graph homomorphisms — in that context, Theorem 4.1 of [8] allows pinning all variables to a particular component of the target graph H𝐻H.

Lemma 7.

For every ℱ⊆ℱqℱsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{q}, #CSP​(ℱ∪⋃c∈[q]δc)≤T#CSP​(ℱ)subscriptT#CSPℱsubscript𝑐delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝛿𝑐#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\bigcup_{c\in[q]}\delta_{c})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}).

The proof of Lemma 7 is deferred to the appendix. Since we only use the case q=2𝑞2q=2 in this paper, we provide the (simpler) proof for the Boolean case here.

Lemma 8.

For every ℱ⊆ℱ2ℱsubscriptℱ2\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{2}, #CSP​(ℱ∪{δ0,δ1})≤T#CSP​(ℱ)subscriptT#CSPℱsubscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\{\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}).

Proof.

For x∈[2]k𝑥superscriptdelimited-[]2𝑘x\in[2]^{k}, let x¯¯𝑥\overline{x} be the k𝑘k-tuple whose i𝑖i’th component, x¯isubscript¯𝑥𝑖\overline{x}_{i}, is xi⊕1direct-sumsubscript𝑥𝑖1x_{i}\oplus 1, for all i𝑖i. Say that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is symmetric if it is the case that for every arity-k𝑘k function f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in\mathcal{F} and every x∈[2]k𝑥superscriptdelimited-[]2𝑘x\in[2]^{k}, f​(x¯)=f​(x)𝑓¯𝑥𝑓𝑥f(\overline{x})=f(x).

Given an instance I𝐼I of #CSP​(ℱ∪{δ0,δ1})#CSPℱsubscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\{\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\}) with variable set V𝑉V we consider two instances I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} and I′′superscript𝐼′′I^{\prime\prime} of #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}). Let V0subscript𝑉0V_{0} be the set of variables v𝑣v of I𝐼I to which the constraint δ0​(v)subscript𝛿0𝑣\delta_{0}(v) is applied. Let V1subscript𝑉1V_{1} be the set of variables v𝑣v of I𝐼I to which the constraint δ1​(v)subscript𝛿1𝑣\delta_{1}(v) is applied. We can assume without loss of generality that V0subscript𝑉0V_{0} and V1subscript𝑉1V_{1} do not intersect. (Otherwise, Z​(I)=0𝑍𝐼0Z(I)=0 and we can determine this without using an oracle for #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}).) Let V2=V∖(V0∪V1)subscript𝑉2𝑉subscript𝑉0subscript𝑉1V_{2}=V\setminus(V_{0}\cup V_{1}). The instance I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} has variables V2∪{t0,t1}subscript𝑉2subscript𝑡0subscript𝑡1V_{2}\cup\{t_{0},t_{1}\} where t0subscript𝑡0t_{0} and t1subscript𝑡1t_{1} are distinct new variables that are not in V𝑉V. Every constraint C𝐶C of I𝐼I involving a function f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in\mathcal{F} corresponds to a constraint C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} of I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime}. Similarly, the instance I′′superscript𝐼′′I^{\prime\prime} has variables V2∪{t}subscript𝑉2𝑡V_{2}\cup\{t\} where t𝑡t is a new variable that is not in V𝑉V. Solving these, we obtain the value of Z​(I′∣σ​(t0)=0,σ​(t1)=1)=Z​(I)𝑍formulae-sequenceconditionalsuperscript𝐼′𝜎subscript𝑡00𝜎subscript𝑡11𝑍𝐼Z(I^{\prime}\mid\sigma(t_{0})=0,\sigma(t_{1})=1)=Z(I). ∎

2.4 #P-hard problems

To prove Lemma 5, we will give reductions from some known #P-hard problems. The first of these is the problem of counting homomorphisms from simple graphs to 222-vertex multigraphs. We use the following special case of Bulatov and Grohe’s Theorem 3.

Corollary 9 (Bulatov and Grohe [4]).

Let H𝐻H be a symmetric 2×2222\times 2 matrix with non-negative real entries. If H𝐻H has rank 2 and at most one entry of H𝐻H is 00 then Eval(H𝐻H) is #P-hard.

We will also use the problem of computing the weight enumerator of a linear code. Given a generating matrix A∈{0,1}r×C𝐴superscript01𝑟𝐶A\in\{0,1\}^{r\times C} of rank r𝑟r, a code word c𝑐c is any vector in the linear subspace ΥΥ\Upsilon generated by the rows of A𝐴A over GF(2). For any real number λ𝜆\lambda, the weight enumerator of the code is given by WA​(λ)=∑c∈Υλ‖c‖subscript𝑊𝐴𝜆subscript𝑐Υsuperscript𝜆norm𝑐W_{A}(\lambda)=\sum_{c\in\Upsilon}\lambda^{\|c\|}, where ‖c‖norm𝑐\|c\| is the number of 111’s in c𝑐c. The problem of computing the weight enumerator of a linear code is in FP for λ∈{−1,0,1}𝜆101\lambda\in\{-1,0,1\}, and is known to be #P-hard for every other fixed λ∈ℚ𝜆ℚ\lambda\in\mathbb{Q} (see [23]). We could not find a proof, so we provide one here. We restrict attention to positive λ𝜆\lambda, since that is adequate for our purposes.

Lemma 10.

Computing the Weight Enumerator of a Linear Code is #P-hard for any fixed positive rational number λ≠1𝜆1\lambda\neq 1.

Proof.

We will prove hardness by reduction from a problem Eval​(H)Eval𝐻\text{{\sc Eval}}(H), for some appropriate H𝐻H, using Corollary 9. Let the input to Eval​(H)Eval𝐻\text{{\sc Eval}}(H) be a connected graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) with V={v1,…,vn}𝑉subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛V=\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\} and E={e1,…,em}𝐸subscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑚E=\{e_{1},\ldots,e_{m}\}. Let B𝐵B be the n×m𝑛𝑚n\times m incidence matrix of G𝐺G, with bi​j=1subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗1b_{ij}=1 if vi∈ejsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗v_{i}\in e_{j} and bi​j=0subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗0b_{ij}=0 otherwise. Let A𝐴A be the (n−1)×m𝑛1𝑚(n-1)\times m matrix which is B𝐵B with the row for vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} deleted. A𝐴A will be the generating matrix of the Weight Enumerator instance, with r=n−1𝑟𝑛1r=n-1 and C=m𝐶𝑚C=m. It has rank (n−1)𝑛1(n-1) since G𝐺G contains a spanning tree. A code word c𝑐c has cj=⨁i∈Ubi​jsubscript𝑐𝑗subscriptdirect-sum𝑖𝑈subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗c_{j}=\bigoplus_{i\in U}b_{ij}, where U⊆V∖{vn}𝑈𝑉subscript𝑣𝑛U\subseteq V\setminus\{v_{n}\}. Thus cj=1subscript𝑐𝑗1c_{j}=1 if and only if ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j} has exactly one endpoint in U𝑈U, and the weight of c𝑐c is λksuperscript𝜆𝑘\lambda^{k}, where k𝑘k is the number of edges in the cut U,V∖U𝑈𝑉𝑈U,V\setminus U. Thus WA​(λ)=12​ZH​(G)subscript𝑊𝐴𝜆12subscript𝑍𝐻𝐺W_{A}(\lambda)=\frac{1}{2}Z_{H}(G), where H𝐻H is the symmetric weight matrix with H11=H22=1subscript𝐻11subscript𝐻221H_{11}=H_{22}=1 and H12=H21=λsubscript𝐻12subscript𝐻21𝜆H_{12}=H_{21}=\lambda. The 1212\frac{1}{2} arises because we fixed which side of the cut contains vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n}. Now H𝐻H has rank 2 unless λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1, so this problem is #P-hard by Corollary 9. Note, by the way, that ZH​(G)subscript𝑍𝐻𝐺Z_{H}(G) is the partition function of the Ising model in statistical physics [5]. ∎

3 The Proof of Lemma 5

Throughout this section, we assume q=2𝑞2q=2. The following Lemma is a generalisation of a result of Creignou and Hermann [6], which deals with the case in which f𝑓f is a relation (or, in our setting, a function with range {0,1}01\{0,1\}). The inductive technique used in the proof of Lemma 11 (combined with the follow-up in Lemma 12) is good for showing that #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}) is #P-hard when ℱℱ\mathcal{F} contains a single function. A very different situation arises when #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) and #CSP​({g})#CSP𝑔\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{g\}) are in FP but #CSP​({f,g})#CSP𝑓𝑔\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,g\}) is #P-hard due to interactions between f𝑓f and g𝑔g — we deal with that problem later.

Lemma 11.

Suppose that f∈ℱ2𝑓subscriptℱ2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} does not have affine support. Then #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) is #P-hard.

Proof.

Let k𝑘k be the arity of f𝑓f, and let us denote the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\textrm{th}} component of k𝑘k-tuple a∈Rf𝑎subscript𝑅𝑓a\in R_{f} by aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}. The proof is by induction on k𝑘k. The lemma is trivially true for k=1𝑘1k=1, since all functions of arity 111 have affine support.

For k=2𝑘2k=2, we note that since Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} is not affine, it is of the form Rf={(α,β),(α¯,β),(α¯,β¯)}subscript𝑅𝑓𝛼𝛽¯𝛼𝛽¯𝛼¯𝛽R_{f}=\{(\alpha,\beta),(\bar{\alpha},\beta),(\bar{\alpha},\bar{\beta})\} for some α∈{0,1}𝛼01\alpha\in\{0,1\} and β∈{0,1}𝛽01\beta\in\{0,1\}. We can show that #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) is #P-hard by reduction from Eval(H𝐻H) using

H=(f​(0,0)f​(0,1)f​(1,0)f​(1,1)),𝐻𝑓00𝑓01𝑓10𝑓11H=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}f(0,0)&f(0,1)\\ f(1,0)&f(1,1)\\ \end{array}\right),

which has rank 222 and exactly one entry that is 00. Given an instance G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) of Eval(H𝐻H) we construct an instance I𝐼I of #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) as follows. The variables of I𝐼I are the vertices of G𝐺G. For each edge e=(u,v)𝑒𝑢𝑣e=(u,v) of G𝐺G, add a constraint with function f𝑓f and variable sequence u,v𝑢𝑣u,v. Corollary 9 now tells us that Eval(H𝐻H) is #P-hard, so #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) is #P-hard.

Suppose k>2𝑘2k>2. We start with some general arguments and notation. For any i∈{1,…,k}𝑖1…𝑘i\in\{1,\ldots,k\} and any α∈{0,1}𝛼01\alpha\in\{0,1\} let fi=αsuperscript𝑓𝑖𝛼f^{i=\alpha} be the function of arity k−1𝑘1k-1 derived from f𝑓f by pinning the i𝑖i’th position to α𝛼\alpha. That is, fi=α​(x1,…,xk−1)=f​(x1,…,xi−1,α,xi+1,…,xk)superscript𝑓𝑖𝛼subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘1𝑓subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑖1𝛼subscript𝑥𝑖1…subscript𝑥𝑘f^{i=\alpha}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{k-1})=f(x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1},\alpha,x_{i+1},\ldots,x_{k}). Also, let fi=∗superscript𝑓𝑖f^{i=*} be the projection of f𝑓f onto all positions apart from position i𝑖i (see Section 2.2). Note that #CSP​({fi=α})≤T#CSP​({f,δ0,δ1})subscriptT#CSPsuperscript𝑓𝑖𝛼#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{i=\alpha}\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\}), since fi=αsuperscript𝑓𝑖𝛼f^{i=\alpha} can obviously be simulated by {f,δ0,δ1}𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\left\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\right\}. Furthermore, by Lemma 8, #CSP​({f,δ0,δ1})≤T#CSP​({f})subscriptT#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}). Thus, we can assume that fi=αsuperscript𝑓𝑖𝛼f^{i=\alpha} has affine support — otherwise, we are finished by induction. Similarly, by Lemma 6, #CSP​({fi=∗})≤T#CSP​({f})subscriptT#CSPsuperscript𝑓𝑖#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\left\{f^{i=*}\right\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\left\{f\right\}). Thus we can assume that fi=∗superscript𝑓𝑖f^{i=*} has affine support — otherwise, we are finished by induction.

Now, recall that Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} is not affine. Consider any a,b,c∈Rf𝑎𝑏𝑐subscript𝑅𝑓a,b,c\in R_{f} such that d=a⊕b⊕c∉Rf𝑑direct-sum𝑎𝑏𝑐subscript𝑅𝑓d=a\oplus b\oplus c\notin R_{f}. We have 4 cases.

Case 1: There are indices 1≤i<j≤k1𝑖𝑗𝑘1\leq i<j\leq k such that (ai,bi,ci)=(aj,bj,cj)subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝑏𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗(a_{i},b_{i},c_{i})=(a_{j},b_{j},c_{j}):   Without loss of generality, suppose i=1𝑖1i=1 and j=2𝑗2j=2. Define the function f′superscript𝑓′f^{\prime} of arity (k−1)𝑘1(k-1) by f′​(r2,…,rk)=f​(r2,r2,…,rk)superscript𝑓′subscript𝑟2…subscript𝑟𝑘𝑓subscript𝑟2subscript𝑟2…subscript𝑟𝑘f^{\prime}(r_{2},\ldots,r_{k})=f(r_{2},r_{2},\ldots,r_{k}). Note that Rf′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′R_{f^{\prime}} is not affine since the condition a⊕b⊕c∉Rfdirect-sum𝑎𝑏𝑐subscript𝑅𝑓a\oplus b\oplus c\notin R_{f} is inherited by Rf′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′R_{f^{\prime}}. So, by induction, #CSP​({f′})#CSPsuperscript𝑓′\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{\prime}\}) is #P-hard. Now note that #CSP​({f′})≤T#CSP​({f})subscriptT#CSPsuperscript𝑓′#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{\prime}\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}). To see this, note that any instance I1subscript𝐼1I_{1} of #CSP​({f′})#CSPsuperscript𝑓′\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{\prime}\}) can be turned into an instance I𝐼I of #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) by repeating the first variable in the sequence of variables for each constraint.

Case 2: There is an index 1≤i≤k1𝑖𝑘1\leq i\leq k such that ai=bi=cisubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖a_{i}=b_{i}=c_{i}:  Since d𝑑d is not in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} and di=aisubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖d_{i}=a_{i}, we find that fi=aisuperscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖f^{i=a_{i}} does not have affine support, contrary to earlier assumptions.

Having finished Cases 1 and 2, we may assume without loss of generality that we are in Case 3 or Case 4 below, where {α,β}∈{0,1}𝛼𝛽01\left\{\alpha,\beta\right\}\in\left\{0,1\right\}, α¯=1−α¯𝛼1𝛼\bar{\alpha}=1-\alpha, β¯=1−β¯𝛽1𝛽\bar{\beta}=1-\beta and a′,b′,c′∈{0,1}k−2superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′superscript𝑐′superscript01𝑘2a^{\prime},b^{\prime},c^{\prime}\in\left\{0,1\right\}^{k-2}.

Case 3: a=(α¯,β¯,a′)𝑎¯𝛼¯𝛽superscript𝑎′a=(\bar{\alpha},\bar{\beta},a^{\prime}), b=(α¯,β,b′)𝑏¯𝛼𝛽superscript𝑏′b=(\bar{\alpha},\beta,b^{\prime}), c=(α,β¯,c′)𝑐𝛼¯𝛽superscript𝑐′c=(\alpha,\bar{\beta},c^{\prime}):  Since Rf1=∗subscript𝑅superscript𝑓1R_{f^{1=*}} is affine and a𝑎a, b𝑏b and c𝑐c are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, we must have either d=(α,β,d′)∈Rf𝑑𝛼𝛽superscript𝑑′subscript𝑅𝑓d=(\alpha,\beta,d^{\prime})\in R_{f} or e=(α¯,β,d′)∈Rf𝑒¯𝛼𝛽superscript𝑑′subscript𝑅𝑓e=(\bar{\alpha},\beta,d^{\prime})\in R_{f}, where d′=a′⊕b′⊕c′superscript𝑑′direct-sumsuperscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′superscript𝑐′d^{\prime}=a^{\prime}\oplus b^{\prime}\oplus c^{\prime}. In the first case, we are done (we have contradicted the assumption that d∉Rf𝑑subscript𝑅𝑓d\not\in R_{f}), so assume that e∈Rf𝑒subscript𝑅𝑓e\in R_{f} but d∉Rf𝑑subscript𝑅𝑓d\not\in R_{f}. Similarly, since Rf2=∗subscript𝑅superscript𝑓2R_{f^{2=*}} is affine, we may assume that g=(α,β¯,d′)∈Rf𝑔𝛼¯𝛽superscript𝑑′subscript𝑅𝑓g=(\alpha,\bar{\beta},d^{\prime})\in R_{f}. Since Rf2=β¯subscript𝑅superscript𝑓2¯𝛽R_{f^{2=\bar{\beta}}} is affine and a𝑎a, c𝑐c and g𝑔g are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, we find that i=(α¯,β¯,b′)∈Rf𝑖¯𝛼¯𝛽superscript𝑏′subscript𝑅𝑓i=(\bar{\alpha},\bar{\beta},b^{\prime})\in R_{f}. Also, since Rf2=β¯subscript𝑅superscript𝑓2¯𝛽R_{f^{2=\bar{\beta}}} is affine and a𝑎a, hℎh and i𝑖i are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, we find that j=(α¯,β¯,d′)∈Rf𝑗¯𝛼¯𝛽superscript𝑑′subscript𝑅𝑓j=(\bar{\alpha},\bar{\beta},d^{\prime})\in R_{f}. Let f′​(r1,r2)=f​(r1,r2,d3,…,dk)superscript𝑓′subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2𝑓subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2subscript𝑑3…subscript𝑑𝑘f^{\prime}(r_{1},r_{2})=f(r_{1},r_{2},d_{3},\ldots,d_{k}). Thus, f′superscript𝑓′f^{\prime} does not have affine support and #CSP​({f′})#CSPsuperscript𝑓′\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{\prime}\}) is #P-hard by induction. Also, #CSP​({f′})≤T#CSP​({f})subscriptT#CSPsuperscript𝑓′#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{\prime}\})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) by Lemma 8.

Case 4: a=(α¯,α,a′)𝑎¯𝛼𝛼superscript𝑎′a=(\bar{\alpha},\alpha,a^{\prime}), b=(α¯,α,b′)𝑏¯𝛼𝛼superscript𝑏′b=(\bar{\alpha},\alpha,b^{\prime}), c=(α,α¯,c′)𝑐𝛼¯𝛼superscript𝑐′c=(\alpha,\bar{\alpha},c^{\prime}):  Since Rf1=∗subscript𝑅superscript𝑓1R_{f^{1=*}} is affine and a𝑎a, b𝑏b and c𝑐c are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} but d𝑑d is not, we have e=(α¯,α¯,d′)∈Rf𝑒¯𝛼¯𝛼superscript𝑑′subscript𝑅𝑓e=(\bar{\alpha},\bar{\alpha},d^{\prime})\in R_{f}. Similarly, since Rf2=∗subscript𝑅superscript𝑓2R_{f^{2=*}} is affine and a𝑎a, b𝑏b and c𝑐c are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} but d𝑑d is not, we have g=(α,α,d′)∈Rf𝑔𝛼𝛼superscript𝑑′subscript𝑅𝑓g=(\alpha,\alpha,d^{\prime})\in R_{f}. Now since Rf1=α¯subscript𝑅superscript𝑓1¯𝛼R_{f^{1=\bar{\alpha}}} is affine and a𝑎a, b𝑏b and e𝑒e are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, we have h=(α¯,α¯,c′)∈Rfℎ¯𝛼¯𝛼superscript𝑐′subscript𝑅𝑓h=(\bar{\alpha},\bar{\alpha},c^{\prime})\in R_{f}. Let f′​(r1,r2)=f​(r1,r2,c3,…,ck)superscript𝑓′subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2𝑓subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2subscript𝑐3…subscript𝑐𝑘f^{\prime}(r_{1},r_{2})=f(r_{1},r_{2},c_{3},\ldots,c_{k}). Suppose j∈Rf𝑗subscript𝑅𝑓j\in R_{f}. Since Rf1=α¯subscript𝑅superscript𝑓1¯𝛼R_{f^{1=\bar{\alpha}}} is affine and a𝑎a, b𝑏b and j𝑗j are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, we have ℓ=(α¯,α,d′)∈Rfℓ¯𝛼𝛼superscript𝑑′subscript𝑅𝑓\ell=(\bar{\alpha},\alpha,d^{\prime})\in R_{f}. Let f′′​(r1,r2)=f​(r1,r2,d3,…,dk)superscript𝑓′′subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2𝑓subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2subscript𝑑3…subscript𝑑𝑘f^{\prime\prime}(r_{1},r_{2})=f(r_{1},r_{2},d_{3},\ldots,d_{k}). Then f′′superscript𝑓′′f^{\prime\prime} does not have affine support (since e𝑒e, g𝑔g and ℓℓ\ell are in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} but d𝑑d is not) so we finish by induction as in Case 3. ∎

Lemma 11 showed that #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) is #P-hard when f𝑓f does not have affine support. The following lemma gives another (rather technical, but useful) condition which implies that #CSP​({f})#CSP𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\}) is #P-hard. We start with some notation. Let f𝑓f be an arity-k𝑘k function. For a value b∈{0,1}𝑏01b\in\{0,1\}, an index i∈{1,…,k}𝑖1…𝑘i\in\{1,\ldots,k\}, and a tuple y∈{0,1}k−1𝑦superscript01𝑘1y\in\{0,1\}^{k-1}, let yi=bsuperscript𝑦𝑖𝑏{y}^{i=b} denote the tuple x∈{0,1}k𝑥superscript01𝑘x\in\{0,1\}^{k} formed by setting xi=bsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑏x_{i}=b and xj=yjsubscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗x_{j}=y_{j} (j∈{1,…,k}∖{i})𝑗1…𝑘𝑖(j\in\left\{1,\ldots,k\right\}\setminus\left\{i\right\}).

We say that index i𝑖i of f𝑓f is useful if there is a tuple y𝑦y such that f​(yi=0)>0𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖00f({y}^{i=0})>0 and f​(yi=1)>0𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖10f({y}^{i=1})>0. We say that f𝑓f is product-like if, for every useful index i𝑖i, there is a rational number λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} such that, for all y∈{0,1}k−1𝑦superscript01𝑘1y\in\{0,1\}^{k-1},

f​(yi=0)=λi​f​(yi=1).𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖0subscript𝜆𝑖𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖1f({y}^{i=0})=\lambda_{i}f({y}^{i=1}). (2)

If every position i𝑖i of f𝑓f is useful then being product-like is the same as being of product type. However, being product-like is less demanding because it does not restrict indices that are not useful.

Lemma 12.

If f∈ℱ2𝑓subscriptℱ2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not product-like then #CSP({f})𝑓(\{f\}) is #P-hard.

Proof.

We’ll use Corollary 9 to prove hardness, following an argument from [9]. Choose a useful index i𝑖i so that there is no λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} satisfying (2).

Suppose f𝑓f has arity k𝑘k. Let A𝐴A be the 2×2k−12superscript2𝑘12\times 2^{k-1} matrix such that for b∈{0,1}𝑏01b\in\{0,1\} and y∈{0,1}k−1𝑦superscript01𝑘1y\in\{0,1\}^{k-1}, Ab,y=f​(yi=b)subscript𝐴𝑏𝑦𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖𝑏A_{b,y}=f({y}^{i=b}). Let A′=A​ATsuperscript𝐴′𝐴superscript𝐴𝑇A^{\prime}=AA^{T}.

First, we show that Eval(A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}) is #P-hard. Note that A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime} is the following symmetric 2×2222\times 2 matrix with non-negative rational entries.

(∑yA0,y2∑yA0,y​A1,y∑yA0,y​A1,y∑yA1,y2)=(∑yf​(yi=0)2∑yf​(yi=0)​f​(yi=1)∑yf​(yi=0)​f​(yi=1)∑yf​(yi=1)2)subscript𝑦superscriptsubscript𝐴0𝑦2subscript𝑦subscript𝐴0𝑦subscript𝐴1𝑦subscript𝑦subscript𝐴0𝑦subscript𝐴1𝑦subscript𝑦superscriptsubscript𝐴1𝑦2subscript𝑦𝑓superscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖02subscript𝑦𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖0𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖1subscript𝑦𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖0𝑓superscript𝑦𝑖1subscript𝑦𝑓superscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖12\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}\sum_{y}A_{0,y}^{2}&\sum_{y}A_{0,y}A_{1,y}\\ \sum_{y}A_{0,y}A_{1,y}&\sum_{y}A_{1,y}^{2}\\ \end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}\sum_{y}{f({y}^{i=0})}^{2}&\sum_{y}f({y}^{i=0})f({y}^{i=1})\\ \sum_{y}f({y}^{i=0})f({y}^{i=1})&\sum_{y}f({y}^{i=1})^{2}\\ \end{array}\right)

Since index i𝑖i is useful, all four entries of A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime} are positive. To show that Eval(A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}) is #P-hard by Corollary 9, we just need to show that its determinant is non-zero. By Cauchy-Schwartz, the determinant is non-negative, and is zero only if λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} exists, which have assumed not to be the case. Thus Eval(A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}) is #P-hard by Corollary 9.

Now we reduce Eval(A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}) to #CSP({f})𝑓(\{f\}). To do this, take an undirected graph G𝐺G which is an instance of Eval(A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}). Construct an instance Y𝑌Y of #CSP({f})𝑓(\{f\}). For every vertex v𝑣v of G𝐺G we introduce a variable xvsubscript𝑥𝑣x_{v} of Y𝑌Y. Also, for every edge e𝑒e of G𝐺G we introduce k−1𝑘1k-1 variables xe,1,…,xe,k−1subscript𝑥𝑒1…subscript𝑥𝑒𝑘1x_{e,1},\ldots,x_{e,{k-1}} of Y𝑌Y. We introduce constraints in Y𝑌Y as follows. For each edge e=(v,v′)𝑒𝑣superscript𝑣′e=(v,v^{\prime}) of G𝐺G we introduce constraints f​(xv,xe,1,…,xe,k−1)𝑓subscript𝑥𝑣subscript𝑥𝑒1…subscript𝑥𝑒𝑘1f(x_{v},x_{e,1},\ldots,x_{e,k-1}) and f​(xv′,xe,1,…,xe,k−1)𝑓subscript𝑥superscript𝑣′subscript𝑥𝑒1…subscript𝑥𝑒𝑘1f(x_{v^{\prime}},x_{e,1},\ldots,x_{e,k-1}) into Y𝑌Y, where we have assumed, without loss of generality, that the first index is useful.

It is clear that Eval(A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime}) is exactly equal to the partition function of the #CSP({f})𝑓(\{f\}) instance Y𝑌Y. ∎

For w∈ℚ+𝑤superscriptℚw\in\mathbb{Q}^{+}, let Uwsubscript𝑈𝑤U_{w} denote the unary function mapping 0 to 1 and 1 to w𝑤w. Note that U0=δ0subscript𝑈0subscript𝛿0U_{0}=\delta_{0}, and U1subscript𝑈1U_{1} gives the constant (0-ary function) 1, occurrences of which leave the partition function unchanged. So, by Lemma 8, we can discard these constraints since they do not add to the complexity of the problem. Note, by the observation above about proportional functions, that the functions Uwsubscript𝑈𝑤U_{w} include all unary functions except for δ1subscript𝛿1\delta_{1} and the constant 0. We can discard δ1subscript𝛿1\delta_{1} by Lemma 8, and if the constant 0 function is in ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, any instance I𝐼I where it appears as a constraint has Z​(I)=0𝑍𝐼0Z(I)=0. So again we can discard these constraints since they not add to the complexity of the problem.

Thus Uwsubscript𝑈𝑤U_{w} will be called nontrivial if w∉{0,1}𝑤01w\notin\left\{0,1\right\}. Let ⊕k:{0,1}k→{0,1}\oplus_{k}:\{0,1\}^{k}\to\{0,1\} be the arity-k𝑘k parity function that is 1 iff its argument has an odd number of 111s. Let ¬⊕k:{0,1}k→{0,1}:limit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum𝑘→superscript01𝑘01\neg\oplus_{k}:\{0,1\}^{k}\to\{0,1\} be the function 1−⊕k1-\oplus_{k}. The following lemma shows that even a simple function like ⊕3subscriptdirect-sum3\oplus_{3} can lead to intractable #CSP instances when it is combined with a nontrivial weight function Uλsubscript𝑈𝜆U_{\lambda}.

Lemma 13.

#CSP​(⊕3,Uλ,δ0,δ1)#CSPsubscriptdirect-sum3subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\oplus_{3},U_{\lambda},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}) and #CSP​(¬⊕3,Uλ,δ0,δ1)#CSPlimit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\neg\oplus_{3},U_{\lambda},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}) are both #P-hard, for any positive λ≠1𝜆1\lambda\neq 1.

Proof.

We give a reduction from computing the Weight Enumerator of a Linear Code, which was shown to be #P-hard in Lemma 10. In what follows, it is sometimes convenient to view ⊕ksubscriptdirect-sum𝑘\oplus_{k}, δ0subscript𝛿0\delta_{0}, etc., as relations as well as functions to {0,1}01\left\{0,1\right\}.

We first argue that for any k𝑘k, the relation ⊕ksubscriptdirect-sum𝑘\oplus_{k} can be simulated by {⊕3,δ0,δ1}subscriptdirect-sum3subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\left\{\oplus_{3},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\right\}. For example, to simulate x1⊕⋯⊕xkdirect-sumsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑘x_{1}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{k} for k>3𝑘3k>3, take new variables y𝑦y, z𝑧z and w𝑤w and let m=⌈k/2⌉𝑚𝑘2m=\lceil k/2\rceil and use x1⊕⋯⊕xm⊕ydirect-sumsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑚𝑦x_{1}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{m}\oplus y and xm+1⊕⋯⊕xk⊕zdirect-sumsubscript𝑥𝑚1⋯subscript𝑥𝑘𝑧x_{m+1}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{k}\oplus z and y⊕z⊕wdirect-sum𝑦𝑧𝑤y\oplus z\oplus w and δ0​(w)subscript𝛿0𝑤\delta_{0}(w).

Since {⊕3,δ0,δ1}subscriptdirect-sum3subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\left\{\oplus_{3},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\right\} can be used to simulate any relation ⊕ksubscriptdirect-sum𝑘\oplus_{k}, we can use {⊕3,δ0,δ1}subscriptdirect-sum3subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\left\{\oplus_{3},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\right\} to simulate an arbitrary system of linear equations over GF​(2)GF2\mathrm{GF}(2). In particular we can use them to simulate the subspace ΥΥ\Upsilon of code words for a given generating matrix A𝐴A.

Finally, we can use Uλsubscript𝑈𝜆U_{\lambda} to simulate the function which evaluates the weight enumerator on ΥΥ\Upsilon. Then, since λ≠0,1𝜆01\lambda\neq 0,1, we can apply Lemma 10 to complete the argument. The same proof, with minor modifications, applies to ¬⊕3limit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3\neg\oplus_{3}. ∎

Lemma 14.

Suppose f∈ℱ2𝑓subscriptℱ2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not of product type. Then, for any positive λ≠1𝜆1\lambda\neq 1, there exists a constant c𝑐c, depending on f𝑓f, such that #CSP​({f,δ0,δ1,Uλ,Uc})#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝑈𝑐\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1},U_{\lambda},U_{c}\}) is #P-hard.

Proof.

If f𝑓f does not have affine support, the result follows by Lemma 11. So suppose f𝑓f has affine support. Consider the underlying relation Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, viewed as a table. The rows of the table represent the tuples of the relation. Let J𝐽J be the set of columns on which the relation is not constant. That is, if i∈J𝑖𝐽i\in J then there is a row x𝑥x with xi=0subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i}=0 and a row y𝑦y with yi=1subscript𝑦𝑖1y_{i}=1. Group the columns in J𝐽J into equivalence classes: two columns are equivalent iff they are equal or complementary. Let k𝑘k be the number of equivalence classes. Take one column from each of the k𝑘k equivalence classes as a representative, and focus on the arity-k𝑘k relation R𝑅R induced by those columns.

Case 1: Suppose R𝑅R is the complete relation of arity k𝑘k.
Let f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} be the projection of f𝑓f onto the k𝑘k columns of R𝑅R. By Lemma 6,

#CSP​({f∗})≤T#CSP​({f})≤T#CSP​({f,δ0,δ1,Uλ,Uc}).subscriptT#CSPsuperscript𝑓#CSP𝑓subscriptT#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝑈𝑐\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{*}\})\,\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\,\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f\})\,\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\,\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1},U_{\lambda},U_{c}\}).\vspace{-1.4ex}

We will argue that #CSP​({f∗})#CSPsuperscript𝑓\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f^{*}\}) is #P-hard. To see this, note that every column of f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} is useful. Thus, if f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} were product-like, we could conclude that f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} was of product type. But this would imply that f𝑓f is of product type, which is not the case by assumption. So f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} is not product-like and hardness follows from Lemma 12.

Case 2: Suppose R𝑅R is not the complete relation of arity k𝑘k.
We had assumed that Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} is affine. This means that given three vectors, x𝑥x, y𝑦y and z𝑧z, in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f}, x⊕y⊕zdirect-sum𝑥𝑦𝑧x\oplus y\oplus z is in Rfsubscript𝑅𝑓R_{f} as well. The arity-k𝑘k relation R𝑅R inherits this property, so is also affine.

Choose a minimal set of columns of R𝑅R that do not induce the complete relation. This exists by assumption. Suppose there are j𝑗j columns in this minimal set. Observe that j≠1𝑗1j\neq 1 because there are no constant columns in J𝐽J. Also j≠2𝑗2j\not=2, since otherwise the two columns would be related by equality or disequality, contradicting the preprocessing step. The argument here is that on two columns, R𝑅R cannot have exactly three tuples because it is affine, and having tuples x𝑥x, y𝑦y and z𝑧z in would require the fourth tuple x⊕y⊕zdirect-sum𝑥𝑦𝑧x\oplus y\oplus z. But if it has two tuples then, because there are no constant columns, the only possibilities are either (0,0)00(0,0) and (1,1)11(1,1), or (0,1)01(0,1) and (1,0)10(1,0). Both contradict the preprocessing step, so j≥3𝑗3j\geq 3.

Let R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} be the restriction of R𝑅R to the j𝑗j columns. Now R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} of course has fewer than 2jsuperscript2𝑗2^{j} rows, and at least 2j−1superscript2𝑗12^{j-1} by minimality. It is affine, and hence must be ⊕jsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗\oplus_{j} or ¬⊕jlimit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗\neg\oplus_{j}. To see this, first note that the size of R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} has to be a power of 222 since R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} is the solution to a system of linear equations. Hence the size of R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} must be 2j−1superscript2𝑗12^{j-1}. Then, since there are j𝑗j variables, there can only be one defining equation. And, since every subset of j−1𝑗1j-1 variables induces a complete relation, this single equation must involve all variables. Therefore, the equation is ⊕jsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗\oplus_{j} or ¬⊕jlimit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum𝑗\neg\oplus_{j}.

Let f′superscript𝑓′f^{\prime} be the projection of f𝑓f onto the j𝑗j columns just identified. Let f′′superscript𝑓′′f^{\prime\prime} be further obtained by pinning all but three of the j𝑗j variables to 0. Pinning j−3𝑗3j-3 variables to 00 leaves a single equation involving all three remaining variables. Thus Rf′′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′′R_{f^{\prime\prime}} must be ⊕3subscriptdirect-sum3\oplus_{3} or ¬⊕3limit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3\neg\oplus_{3}.

Now define the symmetric function f′′′superscript𝑓′′′f^{\prime\prime\prime} by

f′′′​(a,b,c)=f′′​(a,b,c)​f′′​(a,c,b)​f′′​(b,a,c)​f′′​(b,c,a)​f′′​(c,a,b)​f′′​(c,b,a),superscript𝑓′′′𝑎𝑏𝑐superscript𝑓′′𝑎𝑏𝑐superscript𝑓′′𝑎𝑐𝑏superscript𝑓′′𝑏𝑎𝑐superscript𝑓′′𝑏𝑐𝑎superscript𝑓′′𝑐𝑎𝑏superscript𝑓′′𝑐𝑏𝑎f^{\prime\prime\prime}(a,b,c)=f^{\prime\prime}(a,b,c)\*f^{\prime\prime}(a,c,b)\*f^{\prime\prime}(b,a,c)\*f^{\prime\prime}(b,c,a)\*f^{\prime\prime}(c,a,b)\*f^{\prime\prime}(c,b,a),\vspace{-1.4ex}

Note that Rf′′′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′′′R_{f^{\prime\prime\prime}} is ⊕3subscriptdirect-sum3\oplus_{3} or ¬⊕3limit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3\neg\oplus_{3}, since Rf′′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′′R_{f^{\prime\prime}} is symmetric and hence Rf′′′=Rf′′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′′′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′′R_{f^{\prime\prime\prime}}=R_{f^{\prime\prime}}.

To summarise: using f𝑓f and the constant functions δ0subscript𝛿0\delta_{0} and δ1subscript𝛿1\delta_{1}, we have simulated a function f′′′superscript𝑓′′′f^{\prime\prime\prime} such that its underlying relation Rf′′′subscript𝑅superscript𝑓′′′R_{f^{\prime\prime\prime}} is either ⊕3subscriptdirect-sum3\oplus_{3} or ¬⊕3limit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3\neg\oplus_{3}. Furthermore, if triples x𝑥x and y𝑦y have the same number of 111s then f′′′​(x)=f′′′​(y)superscript𝑓′′′𝑥superscript𝑓′′′𝑦f^{\prime\prime\prime}(x)=f^{\prime\prime\prime}(y).

We can now simulate an unweighted version of ⊕3subscriptdirect-sum3\oplus_{3} or ¬⊕3limit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3\neg\oplus_{3} using f′′′superscript𝑓′′′f^{\prime\prime\prime} and a unary function Ucsubscript𝑈𝑐U_{c}, with c𝑐c set to a conveniently-chosen value. There are two cases. Suppose first that the affine support of f′′′superscript𝑓′′′f^{\prime\prime\prime} is ¬⊕3limit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3\neg\oplus_{3}. Then let w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} denote the value of f′′′superscript𝑓′′′f^{\prime\prime\prime} when applied to the 333-tuple (0,0,0)000(0,0,0) and let w2subscript𝑤2w_{2} denote f′′′​(0,1,1)=f′′′​(1,0,1)=f′′′​(1,1,0)superscript𝑓′′′011superscript𝑓′′′101superscript𝑓′′′110f^{\prime\prime\prime}(0,1,1)=f^{\prime\prime\prime}(1,0,1)=f^{\prime\prime\prime}(1,1,0). Recall that f′′′​(x)=0superscript𝑓′′′𝑥0f^{\prime\prime\prime}(x)=0 for any other 333-tuple x𝑥x. Now let c=(w0/w2)1/2𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑤0subscript𝑤212c={(w_{0}/w_{2})}^{1/2}. Define a function g𝑔g of arity 3 by g​(α,β,γ)=Uc​(α)​Uc​(β)​Uc​(γ)​f′′′​(α,β,γ)𝑔𝛼𝛽𝛾subscript𝑈𝑐𝛼subscript𝑈𝑐𝛽subscript𝑈𝑐𝛾superscript𝑓′′′𝛼𝛽𝛾g(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)=U_{c}(\alpha)U_{c}(\beta)U_{c}(\gamma)f^{\prime\prime\prime}(\alpha,\beta,\gamma). The other case, in which the affine support of f′′′superscript𝑓′′′f^{\prime\prime\prime} is ⊕3subscriptdirect-sum3\oplus_{3}, is similar.

We have established a reduction from either #CSP​(⊕3,Uλ,δ0,δ1)#CSPsubscriptdirect-sum3subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\oplus_{3},U_{\lambda},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}) or #CSP​(¬⊕3,Uλ,δ0,δ1)#CSPlimit-fromsubscriptdirect-sum3subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\neg\oplus_{3},U_{\lambda},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}), which are both #P-hard by Lemma 13. ∎

Lemma 15.

If f∈ℱ2𝑓subscriptℱ2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not of product type, then #CSP​({f,δ0,δ1,Uλ})#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1subscript𝑈𝜆\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1},U_{\lambda}\}) is #P-hard for any positive λ≠1𝜆1\lambda\neq 1.

Proof.

Take an instance I𝐼I of #CSP​({f,δ0,δ1,Uλ,Uc})#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1subscript𝑈𝜆subscript𝑈𝑐\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1},U_{\lambda},U_{c}\}), from Lemma 14, with n𝑛n variables x1,x2,…,xnsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}. We want to compute the partition function Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I) using only instances of #CSP​({f,δ0,δ1,Uλ})#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1subscript𝑈𝜆\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1},U_{\lambda}\}). That is, instances which avoid using constraints Ucsubscript𝑈𝑐U_{c}. For each i𝑖i, let misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} denote the number of copies of Ucsubscript𝑈𝑐U_{c} that are applied to xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}, and let m=∑i=1nmi𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖m=\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}. Then we can write the partition function as Z​(I)=Z​(I;c)𝑍𝐼𝑍𝐼𝑐Z(I)=Z(I;c) where

Z​(I;w)=∑σ∈{0,1}nZ^​(σ)​∏i:σi=1wmi=∑σ∈{0,1}nZ^​(σ)​w∑i=1nmi​σi,𝑍𝐼𝑤subscript𝜎superscript01𝑛^𝑍𝜎subscriptproduct:𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖1superscript𝑤subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝜎superscript01𝑛^𝑍𝜎superscript𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖Z(I;w)=\sum_{\sigma\in{\{0,1\}}^{n}}\hat{Z}(\sigma)\prod_{i:\sigma_{i}=1}w^{m_{i}}=\sum_{\sigma\in{\{0,1\}}^{n}}\hat{Z}(\sigma)w^{\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}\sigma_{i}},

where Z^​(σ)^𝑍𝜎\hat{Z}(\sigma) denotes the value corresponding to the assignment σ​(xi)=σi𝜎subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖\sigma(x_{i})=\sigma_{i}, ignoring constraints applying Ucsubscript𝑈𝑐U_{c}, and w𝑤w is a variable. So Z^​(σ)^𝑍𝜎\hat{Z}(\sigma) is the weight of σ𝜎\sigma, taken over all constraints other than those applying Ucsubscript𝑈𝑐U_{c}. Note also that Z​(I;w)𝑍𝐼𝑤Z(I;w) is a polynomial of degree m𝑚m in w𝑤w. We can evaluate Z​(I;w)𝑍𝐼𝑤Z(I;w) at the point w=λj𝑤superscript𝜆𝑗w=\lambda^{j} by replacing each Ucsubscript𝑈𝑐U_{c} constraint with j𝑗j copies of a Uλsubscript𝑈𝜆U_{\lambda} constraint. This evaluation is an instance of #CSP​({f,δ0,δ1,Uλ})#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1subscript𝑈𝜆\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\left\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1},U_{\lambda}\right\}). So, using m𝑚m different values of j𝑗j and interpolating, we learn the coefficients of the polynomial Z​(I;w)𝑍𝐼𝑤Z(I;w). Then we can put w=c𝑤𝑐w=c to evaluate Z​(I)𝑍𝐼Z(I). ∎

Lemma 16.

Suppose f∈ℱ2𝑓subscriptℱ2f\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not of product type, and g∈ℱ2𝑔subscriptℱ2g\in\mathcal{F}_{2} is not pure affine. Then #CSP​({f,g,δ0,δ1})#CSP𝑓𝑔subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,g,\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\}) is #P-hard.

Proof.

If g𝑔g does not have affine support we are done by Lemma 11. So suppose that g𝑔g has affine support. Since g𝑔g is not pure affine, the range of g𝑔g contains at least two non-zero values.

The high-level idea will be to use pinning and bisection to extract a non-trivial unary weight function Uλsubscript𝑈𝜆U_{\lambda} from g𝑔g. Then we can reduce from #CSP​({f,δ0,δ1,Uλ})#CSP𝑓subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1subscript𝑈𝜆\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,\delta_{0},\delta_{1},U_{\lambda}\}), which we proved #P-hard in Lemma 15.

Look at the relation Rgsubscript𝑅𝑔R_{g}, viewed as a table. If every column were constant, then g𝑔g would be pure affine, so this is not the case. Select a non-constant column with index hℎh. If there are two non-zero values in the range of g𝑔g amongst the rows of Rgsubscript𝑅𝑔R_{g} that are 00 in column hℎh then we derive a new function g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime} by pinning column hℎh to 00. The new function g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime} is not pure affine, since the two non-zero values prevent this. So we will show inductively that #CSP​({f,g′,δ0,δ1})#CSP𝑓superscript𝑔′subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\left\{f,g^{\prime},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\right\}) is #P-hard. This will give the result since #CSP​({f,g′,δ0,δ1})#CSP𝑓superscript𝑔′subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,g^{\prime},\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\}) trivially reduces to #CSP​({f,g,δ0,δ1})#CSP𝑓𝑔subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\{f,g,\delta_{0},\delta_{1}\}).

If we don’t finish this way, or symmetrically by pinning column hℎh to 111, then we know that there are distinct positive values w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} and w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} such that, for every row x𝑥x of Rgsubscript𝑅𝑔R_{g} with 00 in column hℎh, g​(x)=w0𝑔𝑥subscript𝑤0g(x)=w_{0} and, for every row x𝑥x of Rgsubscript𝑅𝑔R_{g} with 111 in column hℎh, g​(x)=w1𝑔𝑥subscript𝑤1g(x)=w_{1}. Now note that, because the underlying relation Rgsubscript𝑅𝑔R_{g} is affine, it has the same number of 00’s in column hℎh as 111’s. This is because Rgsubscript𝑅𝑔R_{g} is the solution of a set of linear equations. Adding the equation xh=0subscript𝑥ℎ0x_{h}=0 or xh=1subscript𝑥ℎ1x_{h}=1 exactly halves the set of solutions in either case. We now project onto the index set {h}ℎ\left\{h\right\}. We obtain the unary weight function Uλsubscript𝑈𝜆U_{\lambda}, with λ=w1/w0𝜆subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0\lambda=w_{1}/w_{0}, on using the earlier observation about proportional functions. This was our goal, and completes the proof. ∎

Lemma 5 now follows from Lemma 8 and Lemma 16, completing the proof of Theorem 4.

4 Appendix

The purpose of this appendix is to prove Lemma 7 for an arbitrary fixed domain [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. We used only the special case q=2𝑞2q=2, which we stated and proved as Lemma 8. However, pinning appears to be a useful technique for studying the complexity of #CSP, so we give a proof of the general Lemma 7, which we believe will be applicable elsewhere.

Lemma 7.

For every ℱ⊆ℱqℱsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{q}, #CSP​(ℱ∪⋃c∈[q]δc)≤T#CSP​(ℱ)subscriptT#CSPℱsubscript𝑐delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝛿𝑐#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\bigcup_{c\in[q]}\delta_{c})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}).

In order to prove the lemma, we introduce a useful, but less natural, variant of #CSP. Suppose ℱ⊆ℱqℱsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{q}. An instance I𝐼I of #CSP≠​(ℱ)superscript#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}^{\neq}(\mathcal{F}) consists of a set V𝑉V of variables and a set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} of constraints, just like an instance of #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}). In addition, the instance may contain a single extra constraint C𝐶C applying the arity-q𝑞q disequality relation χ≠subscript𝜒\chi_{\neq} with scope (vC,1,…,vC,q)subscript𝑣𝐶1…subscript𝑣𝐶𝑞(v_{C,1},\ldots,v_{C,q}).

The disequality relation χ≠subscript𝜒\chi_{\neq} is defined by χ≠​(x1,…,xq)=1subscript𝜒subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑞1\chi_{\neq}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{q})=1 if x1,…,xq∈[q]subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑞delimited-[]𝑞x_{1},\ldots,x_{q}\in[q] are pairwise distinct. That is, if they are a permutation of the domain [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. Otherwise, χ≠​(x1,…,xq)=0subscript𝜒subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑞0\chi_{\neq}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{q})=0.

Lemma 7 follows immediately from Lemma 17 and 18 below.

Lemma 17.

For every ℱ⊆ℱqℱsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{q}, #CSP​(ℱ∪⋃c∈[q]δc)≤T#CSP≠​(ℱ)subscriptT#CSPℱsubscript𝑐delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝛿𝑐superscript#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\bigcup_{c\in[q]}\delta_{c})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}^{\neq}(\mathcal{F}).

Proof.

We follow the proof lines of Lemma 8, but instead of subtracting the contribution corresponding to configurations in which some tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}’s get the same value, we use the disequality relation to restrict the partition function to configurations in which they get distinct values.

Say that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is symmetric if it is the case that for every arity-k𝑘k function f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in\mathcal{F} and every tuple x∈[q]k𝑥superscriptdelimited-[]𝑞𝑘x\in[q]^{k} and every permutation π:[q]→[q]:𝜋→delimited-[]𝑞delimited-[]𝑞\pi:[q]\rightarrow[q], f​(x1,…,xk)=f​(π​(x1),…,π​(xk))𝑓subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘𝑓𝜋subscript𝑥1…𝜋subscript𝑥𝑘f(x_{1},\ldots,x_{k})=f(\pi(x_{1}),\ldots,\pi(x_{k})).

Let I𝐼I be an instance of #CSP​(ℱ∪⋃c∈[q]δc)#CSPℱsubscript𝑐delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝛿𝑐\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}\cup\bigcup_{c\in[q]}\delta_{c}) with variable set V𝑉V. Let Vcsubscript𝑉𝑐V_{c} be the set of variables v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in V to which the constraint δc​(v)subscript𝛿𝑐𝑣\delta_{c}(v) is applied. Assume without loss of generality that the sets Vcsubscript𝑉𝑐V_{c} are pairwise disjoint. Let Vq=V∖⋃c∈[q]Vcsubscript𝑉𝑞𝑉subscript𝑐delimited-[]𝑞subscript𝑉𝑐V_{q}=V\setminus\bigcup_{c\in[q]}V_{c}. We construct an instance I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} of #CSP≠​(ℱ)superscript#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}^{\neq}(\mathcal{F}). The instance has variables Vq∪{t0,…,tq−1}subscript𝑉𝑞subscript𝑡0…subscript𝑡𝑞1V_{q}\cup\{t_{0},\ldots,t_{q-1}\}. Here C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} is the same as C𝐶C except that variables in Vcsubscript𝑉𝑐V_{c} are replaced with tcsubscript𝑡𝑐t_{c}, for each c∈[q]𝑐delimited-[]𝑞c\in[q]. Case 1. ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is symmetric: 

By construction, Z​(I′)=∑y0,…,yq−1Z​(I′∣σ​(t0)=y0,…,σ​(tq−1)=yq−1)𝑍superscript𝐼′subscriptsubscript𝑦0…subscript𝑦𝑞1𝑍formulae-sequenceconditionalsuperscript𝐼′𝜎subscript𝑡0subscript𝑦0…𝜎subscript𝑡𝑞1subscript𝑦𝑞1Z(I^{\prime})=\sum_{y_{0},\ldots,y_{q-1}}Z(I^{\prime}\mid\sigma(t_{0})=y_{0},\ldots,\sigma(t_{q-1})=y_{q-1}), where the sum is over all permutations y0,…,yq−1subscript𝑦0…subscript𝑦𝑞1y_{0},\ldots,y_{q-1} of [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. By symmetry, the summands are all the same, so Z​(I′)=q!​Z​(I′∣σ​(t0)=0,…,σ​(tq−1)=q−1)=q!​Z​(I)𝑍superscript𝐼′𝑞𝑍formulae-sequenceconditionalsuperscript𝐼′𝜎subscript𝑡00…𝜎subscript𝑡𝑞1𝑞1𝑞𝑍𝐼Z(I^{\prime})=q!Z(I^{\prime}\mid\sigma(t_{0})=0,\ldots,\sigma(t_{q-1})=q-1)=q!Z(I).

Lemma 18.

For every ℱ⊆ℱqℱsubscriptℱ𝑞\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{q}, #CSP≠​(ℱ)≤T#CSP​(ℱ)subscriptTsuperscript#CSPℱ#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}^{\neq}(\mathcal{F})\leq_{\mathrm{T}}\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}).

Proof.

We use Möbius inversion for posets, following the lines of the proof of [2, Theorem 8].777Lovász [15] had previously used Möbius inversion in a similar context. Consider the set of partitions of [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q]. Let 0¯¯0\underline{0} denote the partition with q𝑞q singleton classes. Consider the partial order in which η≤θ𝜂𝜃\eta\leq\theta iff every class of η𝜂\eta is a subset of some class of θ𝜃\theta. Define μ​(0¯)=1𝜇¯01\mu(\underline{0})=1 and for any θ≠0¯𝜃¯0\theta\neq\underline{0} define μ​(θ)=−∑η≤θ,η≠θμ​(η)𝜇𝜃subscriptformulae-sequence𝜂𝜃𝜂𝜃𝜇𝜂\mu(\theta)=-\sum_{\eta\leq\theta,\eta\neq\theta}\mu(\eta). Consider the sum ∑η≤θμ​(η)subscript𝜂𝜃𝜇𝜂\sum_{\eta\leq\theta}\mu(\eta). Clearly, this sum is 111 if θ=0¯𝜃¯0\theta=\underline{0}. From the definition of μ𝜇\mu, it is also easy to see that the sum is 00 otherwise, since

∑η≤θμ​(η)=μ​(θ)+∑η≤θ,η≠θμ​(η)=0.subscript𝜂𝜃𝜇𝜂𝜇𝜃subscriptformulae-sequence𝜂𝜃𝜂𝜃𝜇𝜂0\sum_{\eta\leq\theta}\mu(\eta)=\mu(\theta)+\sum_{\eta\leq\theta,\eta\neq\theta}\mu(\eta)=0.

Now let I𝐼I be an instance of #CSP≠​(ℱ)superscript#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}^{\neq}(\mathcal{F}) with a disequality constraint applied to variables t0,…,tq−1subscript𝑡0…subscript𝑡𝑞1t_{0},\ldots,t_{q-1}. Let V𝑉V be the set of variables of I𝐼I. Given a configuration σ:V→[q]:𝜎→𝑉delimited-[]𝑞\sigma:V\rightarrow[q], let ϑ​(σ)italic-ϑ𝜎\vartheta(\sigma) be the partition of [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q] induced by of (σ​(t0),…,σ​(tq−1))𝜎subscript𝑡0…𝜎subscript𝑡𝑞1(\sigma(t_{0}),\ldots,\sigma(t_{q-1})). Thus i𝑖i and j𝑗j in [q]delimited-[]𝑞[q] are in the same class of ϑ​(σ)italic-ϑ𝜎\vartheta(\sigma) iff σ​(ti)=σ​(tj)𝜎subscript𝑡𝑖𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗\sigma(t_{i})=\sigma(t_{j}). We say that a partition η𝜂\eta is consistent with σ𝜎\sigma (written η≼σprecedes-or-equals𝜂𝜎\eta\preccurlyeq\sigma) if η≤ϑ​(σ)𝜂italic-ϑ𝜎\eta\leq\vartheta(\sigma). Note that η≼σprecedes-or-equals𝜂𝜎\eta\preccurlyeq\sigma means that for any i𝑖i and j𝑗j in the same class of η𝜂\eta, σ​(ti)=σ​(tj)𝜎subscript𝑡𝑖𝜎subscript𝑡𝑗\sigma(t_{i})=\sigma(t_{j}).

Let ΩΩ\Omega be the set of configurations σ𝜎\sigma that satisfy all constraints in I𝐼I except possibly the disequality constraint. Then Z​(I)=∑σ∈Ωw​(σ)​𝟙σ𝑍𝐼subscript𝜎Ω𝑤𝜎subscript1𝜎Z(I)=\sum_{\sigma\in\Omega}w(\sigma)\mathds{1}_{\sigma}, where 𝟙σ=1subscript1𝜎1\mathds{1}_{\sigma}=1 if σ𝜎\sigma respects the disequality constraint, meaning that ϑ​(σ)=0¯italic-ϑ𝜎¯0\vartheta(\sigma)=\underline{0}, and 𝟙σ=0subscript1𝜎0\mathds{1}_{\sigma}=0 otherwise. By the Möbius inversion formula derived above,

Z​(I)=∑σ∈Ωw​(σ)​∑η≤ϑ​(σ)μ​(η).𝑍𝐼subscript𝜎Ω𝑤𝜎subscript𝜂italic-ϑ𝜎𝜇𝜂Z(I)\,=\,\sum_{\sigma\in\Omega}w(\sigma)\sum_{\eta\leq\vartheta(\sigma)}\mu(\eta).

Changing the order of summation, we get

Now note that ∑σ:η≼σw​(σ)subscript:𝜎precedes-or-equals𝜂𝜎𝑤𝜎\sum_{\sigma:\eta\preccurlyeq\sigma}w(\sigma) is the partition function Z​(Iη)𝑍subscript𝐼𝜂Z(I_{\eta}) of an instance Iηsubscript𝐼𝜂I_{\eta} of #CSP​(ℱ)#CSPℱ\mbox{\sf\#CSP}(\mathcal{F}).
